review_title: The Good, The Bad, The Ugly
pros:
- Low expectations for work hours -- just 35 a week, for most staff. Good vacation allotment to start, as well, and a paid break at Christmas.
- Benefits aren't the best around, but prescription meds gets 100% coverage and is awesome.
- Consultative and collaborative work environments. Call it the result of academia, but there's lots of consultation before anything proceeds. Unfortunately, this can also slow things down a lot!
- Beautiful campus. Good transit access (because students), tough parking -- expensive, scarce, but very secure (unfortunately, secure bike storage is severely lacking).
- Newly flexible on work-from-home for many teams.
cons:
- No internal hiring mechanism, so no prospects for moving around without knowing the right person at the right time. 
- Hiring Managers completely unsupervised by HR, and unaccountable for their practices.
- HR support and presence is non-existent for regular employees. 
- Diversity & equity statements not put into in practice in hiring.
- Salaries for many roles are low compared to private sector, and annual increases are non-negotiable -- and unexplained.
- No breaks on tuition for employees (can sign up for Continuing Ed courses, but only on a waitlist) 
- Many teams are running lean and have no prospects of adding FTE due to the way headcount are approved.
- As with any large employer, loaded with bureaucracy and short on information and guidance to navigate the bureaucracy. A real culture of "you are supposed just to know that" pervades. Some admin seem to take pleasure in throwing up blocks. A few departments have committed to good service!

review_title: Keep your dignity and stay far from this place
pros: The benefits package. How difficult it is for them to fire permanent staff (which is also a con). Lax supervision means you can arrive late and leave early - great for people with children.
cons:
Absolutely horrible place to work. Super bureaucratic. It's a old boys club at its worst. 

They only place value on the ideas of senior staff, most of whom are terrible at their job - not just because how they manage people but because their results demonstrate such. 

If you are harassed or bullied, and you choose to report it, the university HR will treat you like you are the problem. The university will then try to discredit you in any way they can. They will try desperately to use anything about you against you. For example, if you have seen a doctor or health care worker in the last three years, they will argue that you are someone with problems and so you fell apart too easy. 

If you want a job with stability, it's the place for you. If you want a job that excites you and that has room for advancement and increasing responsibility, if you want a respectful workplace where your basic human rights are respected, stay far away from this train wreck.

If this were a non-profit or a company, it would have gone under long ago.

review_title: I have had a very good experience working at the University of Victoria
pros: Being a teaching assistant has been quite a pleasant experience for me. I have worked with multiple professors and all of them have been very courteous and welcoming. I personally value the excellent work-life balance as I, in general, do not feel overworked. On the other hand, this is something that could vary depending on which professors and/or department you are working with, so do keep that in mind. However, based on what I have heard from multiple people across various departments, my general outlook is shared by a lot of other people.
cons: The pay for teaching assistants is not nearly competitive enough when compared with universities elsewhere in the country. I am personally familiar with universities in Southern Ontario where pay for comparable jobs is significantly higher and cost of living is similar to Victoria.

review_title: Not perfect but provides a broad variety of career opportunities
pros:
UVIC's career services and co-op opportunities in BC is unique even better than UBC
Tuition fees are very low for graduate students, even int'l students
Best weather in Canada
UVIC's teamwork culture at all levels is admirable, totally democratic governance, respect and supportive of employees and students
The University will soon prosper in terms of academic quality and reputation
cons:
Victoria is a small city so there are less variable job opportunities available
Housing costs in such small city are high
Although Vancouver seems close, it takes at least 3:30 hours to get there from Victoria

review_title: My favourite job experience thus far!
pros: As a CUPE (union) member the work/life balance was really good.  Great coworkers; I lucked out and was in a great unit with a great manager - not everyone is so lucky.  Opportunities to expand skills.  I thought the pay was really good and the benefits excellent.  The campus is beautiful.
cons:
Bad upper-management who are out of touch with their employees.  Not a lot of movement pay wise for CUPE employees.  Make sure you get job evaluation after a few years, or change to higher pay grade if you want to make more money.

Oh yeah, watch out for the scourge of tent caterpillars that descend on the campus every year.  Nightmare inducing.

review_title: A good place to enjoy work-life balance, though not necessarily career advancement.
job_title: Special Projects Assistant in Victoria, BC
pros: Managers at the University of Victoria are very sensitive to work-life balance. They are happy to allow time off for medical appointments, funerals and other life disruptions. They don't make you feel guilty for staying home with the flu. The workload here is not too high - it's rare to see people stay past 5 p.m. on a regular basis.
cons: If you don't have a PhD, you'll be passed over for promotions. Perhaps, as with most universities, they promote their own. And if you don't have a PhD, it can be hard to sit in meetings; you'll find your opinion is not taken as seriously.

pros: Brilliant professors who care. This is a University growing with prestige every year. The research group that I'm in is well connected with industry in the area. A very welcoming environment to be working in.
cons: Funding is contingent on government grants which vary every year. As with most research jobs job security can be an issue.  In general, as a teaching assistant, the rates are low compared to other universities and in most graduate student departments there is little office space for graduate students

pros: As you're part of a union, it's nice to have that protection to make sure you're paid properly for overtime, get vacation time, sick days, etc. There are also opportunities for professional development within different divisions and departments on campus. The UVic community is overall very positive, so the work culture isn't bad either. Beautiful, small/medium-sized campus. Cushy job.
cons: Not an uncommon problem with post-secondary institutions (due to bureaucracy and other issues) — there are a lot of hoops to jump through in order to make the smallest technological improvements, whether it's related to UVic's web presence or the software used to do your work.

review_title: Lots of pro's, not too many cons.
pros:
Good benefits, especially for retirement savings.
Major Victoria transportation hub -- you can get to anywhere from UVic.  
Beautiful campus -- its always a pleasure to be on campus, there's always somewhere nice to walk.
I never have to make lunches (or dinner) (or breakfast!)-- plenty of inexpensive, healthy, and excellent quality food selections.
CARSA -- awesome gym, right on campus.
You can take university courses!
Relaxed work environment, not too much pressure.  Unless perhaps you're on the tenure track... :D
cons:
Salaries not as high as the same work in the private sector.  That's my major disincentive.
Extended health care benefits could be better.

pros:
green space
the students
my colleagues
professional development opportunities
always something interesting happening!
can commute to work by bike
cons:
salary adjustments do not keep up with inflation
opportunities for advancement is limited in some departments
some managers were put in place without supervisory/HR training
limited parking if you drive

pros:
- Beautiful campus -- best in Canada, undoubtedly. 
- Great vacation and sick day entitlements for mid- to senior-level roles.
- Good benefits and strong pension programs.
- Lots of opportunities to move around in your career.
- Good IT and systems support.
- Strong leadership from middle management to VP levels and up.
- Subsidized bus passes are a great deal (half price).
- Work-life balance - 35 hour work-week, and rare need for after-hours work.
- University Club membership free for your first year (go sign up!), has benefits off-campus as well. 
- Access to continuing education (although it's only if space is available, and you do still have to pay some of fees -- this is a con, but the access overall is a positive)
cons:
- While benefits and leave are generous, pay is low for mid- to senior-level roles. HR isn't involved in hiring process, but parachutes in to determine starting pay, and it's virtually non-negotiable.
- Decentralized services (HR, Comms, etc) make for a lot of duplication. Hybrid roles in every department mean you have a lot of half-qualified people doing whatever they think is right, which actually damages the University's profile. HR is not involved in hiring processes until offers are being made.
- Starting new at UVic involves a lot of "figure it out for yourself".
- Some employees clearly take what they have for granted.
- Mix of unions/agreements in a single office can be confusing (ie who has seniority over who, who's entitled to pick vacation days first, etc).
- Parking fees - no break for employees.
- No subsidy for using personal phone for work, and it's expected you will.
- Pro-Dev fund allotments are low, unclear if you can get more.
- Lack of safe bike storage (for a campus pushing employees to bike or bus!)
- Paying for fitness access?! Should be free for FTEs.

pros: Some* Departments are great to work for. Only some.
cons: Your salary is not decided by your boss or even the Dean of your department, it is decided by HR and they have no idea what half the positions in the University even do. You get paid 20% less than government jobs (with similar benefits) and at least 50% less than the private sector, and that's being conservative. The union is useless and lets the University walk all over them. I might get laid off because the union refused to negotiate a better deal with the university and allowed them to bypass the collective agreement. Avoid at all costs.

pros: Beautiful Campus, decent medical benefits
cons: Often a toxic work environment with outdated hierarchy. Lacking equality and labour standards they actually follow and often critical of people with disabilities and mental health issues even though they claim to support.  Frequent workplace bullying which usually leads to mental health issues for the person targeted as there is often no recourse for staff dealing with bullying or poor managers and faculty members who engage in such behaviour.

pros:
flexible time
being always up to date in your research area
publishing papers
traveling and attending conferences
team work
working with different companies and making a wide network
cons:
low salary
sometimes being stocked in wrong direction of research
sometimes working alone
there are no benefits or other bonuses
It's not a permanent job you can rely on it
your work limits to your supervisor expertise

pros: Great to work with students and gain valuable teaching experience. Great TA network and support from peers. Direct deposit was a plus.
cons: Projected hours for the payment of some positions are far under budgeted, easy to work too many hours and thus be under paid. We simply have to work smart and do our best to get as much done while keeping track of the hours.

job_title: Teaching Assistant Consultant in Victoria, BC
pros: Worked as a teaching assistant and teaching assistant consultant for 2 years, great experience, really learn a lot more about a subject by teaching it.
cons: Not much to list for cons - some times the marking load can get heavy, right about same time as all your projects are coming due - but good time management takes care of this.

job_title: Finance Director GSS in Victoria, BC
pros: Amazing environment, good learning experience, great teamwork. An excellent opportunity to learn not only technical skills but also soft skills like collaboration and teamwork. Being in grad school allows people to try new things, make mistakes, and learn hands-on without fear. Further, you push yourself higher-level thinking skills by forcing you to think about different points of view. This also develops social skills, positive cultural relations, self-esteem, and self-management skills.
cons: I have nothing bad to say.

pros: The University of Victoria has jogging trails and beautiful forest all around it.
cons: No union for research assistants. Grant-funded work in this area inhibits job security for the employee and research progress for the employer.

pros: Benefits are good. Casual work environment, room for movement. Learning environment. It really depends on the manager that you work for and department that you are working in.
cons: Seniority based, hard to get rid of incompetence, can be highly political/hierarchal. Some departments are overwhelmed. It really depends on the manager that you work for and department that you are working in. It's who you know, not what you have done.

pros: UVic has a good and relaxed atmosphere. Most of the stuff support us kindly. Especially Computer help desk and librarians are very useful and efficient.
cons: The problem of UVIC are those: it is difficult to find the parking space after 9:00 am. And noon is the worst time to find the parking space. UVIC has a loop road. You can not park a car by the PASS (you need a special pass)inside of the loop.

pros:
Amazing People to Work with. 
I always felt challenged. 
Felt supported by my supervisor. Learned a lot of relevant research experience. Learned how to communicate and develop at a professional setting.
cons: It is very result oriented. What I mean is you must deliver on what you said you have delivered, at the time you said you would deliver. Sometimes this can stress people but I really do well in work settings as such.

job_title: Junior Research Assistant in Victoria, BC
pros: This is a wonderful place to begin a research career.  The staff are very helpful and there are a variety of interdisciplinary opportunities.
cons: Because this is an academic institution, the opportunities for growth are limited solely to education and employment for Bachelor's Degree graduates are minimal.

pros: It's a diverse and inclusive environment.  There are lots of cross collaboration between different faculties and departments.
cons: Funding can be a challenge.  There is a high competition at UVic so you have to be very strong with your grand writing skills.

review_title: Overall, pretty nice place to work.
job_title: Web Applications Developer in Victoria, BC
pros: Healthy work-lief balance, easy to get funding for tools and equipment, casual atmosphere, very nice campus, lots of vacation time.
cons: Lower end of the pay scale. A ton of meetings - it's easy to spend more time in meetings than getting work done.

pros: great supervisors, very helpful staff, great coworkers, a very nice city with great weather, nice and beautiful campus, and good department.
cons: Lack of management skills for some departments, a little bit low pay, payments are not very secure for some departments, facilities not very great for some fields. Not a very big campus, few restaurants and fast food places on campus.

review_title: This job makes me want to get up in the morning!!! Uvic is awesome!!!
pros: Uvic treats everybody equally, it's the first time in my life I felt great and secure about my job!!!
cons: Paying for a full day of parking when you only work 5 hours a day :(

review_title: A teaching assistant in Electrical and Computer Engineering Department
pros: Nice working environment, great people to get along with. The university also provides you with great opportunities to learn how to behave professionally.  You get paid on time.
cons: Most of the time, you are dealing with the most fundamental problems encountered by the students. It may not be that fun and challenging.

job_title: International Student Recruitment Clerk in Victoria, BC
pros: The people and atmosphere are great. The benefits are wonderful and appreciated. I love the fact that you can move around with jobs to find exactly where you fit best.
cons: Not many. We get paid well but are the lowest paid in Canada compared to other institutions.

review_title: it's been a privilege to work with top minds in the academic area I am focusing on.
pros: Flexibility; the opportunity to work with different people from different cultural backgrounds; the instructors usually give a lot of room for TAs to develop their own ideas such as designing the syllabus.
cons: not a lot of room for career development

pros: Some profs are awesome and you get to work with ones that will help you and maybe do research with
cons: Some profs are not helpful and you're one of half a dozen TAs working for one of their large classes. Apparently 26.08 an hour is pretty low as far as TA pay goes

review_title: Solid employer, a bit of bureaucracy
pros: Great, supportive employer on a beautiful campus. Strong central IT department that does great service delivery across tens of thousands of users.
cons: Slow routes of career advancement, since there are a lot of long term union employees. Projects can get bogged down with bureaucracy and academic politics.

review_title: Best part time job a student could ask for.
job_title: Computer Help Desk Analyst in Victoria, BC
pros:
Usually not very stressful.
On campus.
Supervisors schedule around your class schedule.
Good pay.
Friendly co-workers.
Supervisors always have your back and are very helpful.
Rewarding job for those that like helping others.
cons: The job can be extremely busy at times or extremely boring at times.

pros:

review_title: Good to great people, beautiful campus
pros: Ocean Networks Canada does important research in Ocean & Climate studies, ocean geophysics, marine biology and engineering tech for ocean sciences.
cons: Unpaid overtime, serious project planning skills lacking in some areas.

job_title: Engineering Co-op Coordinator in Victoria, BC
pros: I've been at UVic a bit less than a year and so far I love it. Great people.
cons: They are known to keep people in term positions for up to 3 years before making a position permanent; the benefits are not as good as a term employee.

pros: UVic offers training opportunities to all staff to use their software programs.  If you are in the WorkStudy program, your manager will work around your class schedule.
cons: I cannot think about any....I really enjoyed working at UVic.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Victoria, BC
pros: Getting a scholarship, all resources for research are available, big desk and good computer. Freedom in the research, interesting topic
cons: Payment is not much, not much support from experts

pros: good benefits, self contained campus with everything from chapel to gardens, to ood services to hotel to swimming pool and gym to night classes and more

pros: Okay pay, good benefits, good office culture
